descriptionSet.description: In this poster a woman dressed in a pink and gold sari and wearing jewellery can be seen spinning cotton with a lake and mountains in the background. A full moon can also be seen.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: In this poster a woman dressed in a pink and gold sari and wearing jewellery can be seen spinning cotton with a lake and mountains in the background. A full moon can also be seen. (sp)
text-en: Queen of Industry
text-hi: शिल्प रानी
text-transcription-hi: Shilp Rani

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Obviously not all women could experience the leisure, comfort, refinement and autonomy promised by the modern home. Those promises were only available to those wealthy enough to surround themselves by upholstered furniture and framed pictures, to possess enough physical space to sit by themselves without family members crowding in, to own modern technologies like electricity, a telephone, and radios, to be able to learn to read and write. Part of the appeal of these images to elite women may have been that they marked the uniqueness and distinction of their position, their very distance from the lives of the poor, lower castes, and less educated. For those lower classes and castes, on the other hand, part of the appeal of these images may have lain in their vision of a better, ideal world, free of the privations and struggles they faced in daily life. (Abigail McGowan)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Whatever the class, another part of the appeal must have been in how little sacrifice was called for in order to receive the manifest comforts of the modern home. Here women’s leisure is celebrated; that leisure is not depicted as a threat to social standing, successful child rearing, or fiscal responsibility. Nor, despite the overwhelming emphasis in Gandhian and Nehruvian nationalism on restraint, self-denial, and austerity, did images ask women to sacrifice their leisure or comforts for politics. Indeed, for all the nationalist focus on the home in the nineteenth century, it is remarkable how little political charge the home carries in these images. These are thoroughly westernized spaces, in which often the only indication of an Indian setting is the female body, with its iconic sari, gold jewelry, and black hair. And yet even those markers of tradition are ambivalent; saris are paired with modern sleeveless blouses and endlessly changing necklines, jewelry is often reduced to a minimum, and hair is worn in stylish bobs. Few images include nationalist symbolism at all. One that does depicts a ‘Queen of Industry’—a woman happily hand-spinning thread, seated on a balustrade or perhaps the balcony of her home, overlooking a moonlit lake. Although her devotion to spinning clearly roots her in Mohandas Gandhi’s national efforts at uplift through the hand production of cloth, the visual references of the image also connect her elsewhere. (Abigail McGowan)(gs)
